Great game to play, the storyline is pretty good.
This game is probably not any common bullet hell games you would see and the game pace is faster than most usual bullet hell games.

The gameplay is amazing, each stage is unique from the others (you get different enemies that do completely different stuff) and it is also very fast-paced.
For the difficulty, the game itself is relatively difficult as it features different mechanics most other bullet hell games has, but it gets easier once you get the hang of the controls.
You get simple rewards (additional weapons) just by playing (even if you fail).
The soundtrack itself is also good and suiting.
Finally, the graphics and design itself is simply suiting to the theme too.

>Finally, you get Military Sora character in 100% Orange Juice.

10/10 would recommend if you love bullet hell games.

36754509.review:
A truly fantastic game with a compelling story, unique gameplay and wondrous execution.

Taking place before the game Suguri, a war tearing the planet apart threatens to cause the extinction of mankind, by the hands of their own creations: r e p l o i d s.

In all seriousness, I went in this expecting a shallow game with good gameplay that would challenge me, but still be manageable. What I got was a game with a unique, interesting story that made me geniunely feel emotions unseen outside of a special few films and books, with unique characters that had real personality, a real motive behind all of it, and a fair amount of vague description and intrigue to keep me wondering about the details even after I had beaten the game. Furthermore, the gameplay was unlike anything I'd ever seen before, and even more soul-crushing than I expected, offering more challenge than any game I've ever played before (and I've played Touhou.) For fans of bullet hell games who want something to mix the old formula up a bit, this game is perfect, and for entry-level bullet hell/shmup players, it's a great game to come into the genre with.

Pros-
-Appealing, stylized artstyle
-Fair difficulty balance, despite being extremely difficult
-Progression system that rewards you just for attempting levels
-Intriguing story and characters

Cons-
-May turn away people from difficulty
-Controls can be hard to get used to
-Not free

Probably the best game I've played in years.

35757085.review:
Well, after 11 hours of gameplay and making trough the Normal stages, I have to say that Sora is an awesome game.
I like a lot the art style, more than Suguri's , and the mechanics... I LOVED them.
The game seems pretty hard, and, it is. But once you start having more control of the Dash, knowing how and when to use the weapons, and start to know the bosses patterns, it becomes more easy.
You have a lot of weapons, which can make levels more or less easy. A lot of the time you will only use the basic weapons or change one or two, but I think that all of them makes a lot of situations and have a lot of possibilities to use. 
The principal thing you need to master is the Dash. I loved a lot the Dash, because, it doesn't feel bad to use it in a keyboard, so you don't need to buy a Gamepad (and I think it would even be harder to use in a Gamepad). It's confortable and simple, so you only have to put it in a good key to reach and GG. My keybinding was: Z: 1st Weapon , X: 2nd weapon , A: 3rd weapon , Space: Ults , Left Ctrl: Dash , and I recommend it. 
The bosses are pretty unique. Every one have a reason to fight, even if it's a bit hidden (like Alte's husband. You can say that she was an explosive girl). 
All the stages give you a little sub-boss which probably will annoy you a bit, but practice is all you need.
The soundtrack is magnificent, and some helps you to empathize with Sora in some stages.
To summarize, I think that Sora is a very good game, with a good design, bosses, stages, and good (in my opinion) controls, and an OST I'll hear ALL the day, and I higly reccomend it if you like bullet hell games.

35383030.review:
Горизонтальная леталка-стрелялка.
Думаю мастера Touhou Project, Suguri  и пр. такое оценят.
Лично я не особый любитель такого жанра (трясущиеся руки и тонны жалоб в стиле "Я сейчас с ума сойду, прекратите это адовое поливание экрана пулями!". И всеже эту игру купил и прошел (с оговорками).
Что же меня зацепило? Ответ прост - музыка.
Уже после просмотра тизера у меня остались смешанные чувства. С одной стороны - "Укуси меня пчела, опять этот ад из пуль?!", но с другой - "черт возьми, а саундтрек то хорош!". И этого оказалось достаточно.
Игра жутко неприветлива для новичков. [spoiler]Первый запуск - даже меню нет, только изменение настроек и предложение пройти тренировку. Бюджет "мега ультра бомж edition", подумал я.[/spoiler] Даже на легком уровне сложности есть шанс не пройти первую миссию. Просто с непривычки.[spoiler]Но таки пройдя первую миссию, я осознал - в игре есть меню! Лишь в этот момент ты чувствуешь, что игра говорит тебе "Welcome"[/spoiler]
Дальше - еще веселее, в плане сложности.
Адреналина - хоть отбавляй. Напряжно, но не бесит.

Что мне понравилось:
1. Музыка. DEKU однозначно угодил мне.

Что не понравилось:
1. Отчасти - сюжет. [spoiler]Во-первых, он мрачен. Мрачнее чем Suguri. Во-вторых, опять же зная сюжет Suguri, одна вещь после прохождения Extra не укладывается у меня в голове. Временной парадокс просто зашкаливает. Но конец "экстры" всё-таки меня порадовал - именно ЭТОГО я и ждал всю игру.[/spoiler]
2. Сложность и неприветливость игры. "Азиатская" сложность даже в Easy Mode (имеет место мем с Тэви и Рейсен, если вы понимаете о чем я). Да и сама игра выглядит поначалу как что-то до ужаса простое в плане исполнения [spoiler]Не говоря про фон, в меню появляется музыка только после прохождения Extra. И опять же, меню - удел для тех, кто хотя-бы прошел первый уровень. А до этого, впечатление будто меню вообще не существует - ловишь себя на мысли, что игра, как та же Touhou Project (не считая 15 части с её Point Device) вообще проходится "на одном дыхании", что по факту не так.[/spoiler] 
3. Нет русского языка. У меня привычка придираться к такому, не обижайтесь. Я прекрасно понимаю, что это особенность многих японских игр ("study English/Japaneese", все дела), но что уж поделать - раз пустили игру на мировой рынок, то уж вот вам придирочка =)
4. Нет демо-версии. Еще один для меня повод для придирок, обусловленный нежеланием платить за "кота в мешке", даже не смотря на возможность возврата.

По сравнению с Suguri, действительно подтянули графику и качество звука. Цена со скидкой не особо кусачая. Но не помешало бы наличие демо версии (у тех кто не имел дел с играми от Fruitbat Factory есть шанс не "раскусить" всю прелесть этой игры, а "пинка под зад" она дать вполне себе может).
Если вам понравилась музыка из тизера - добро пожаловать, бодрых треков в этой игре хватает.[spoiler]Хотя OST по звучанию несколько отличается от музыки в игре (и дело не в битрейте, некоторые треки, как бы выразиться... remix-нуты, чтоли)[/spoiler]

Игра на любителя. Не смогли пройти первую миссию - помните про "правило 2х часов". Смогли - дальше будет жарче. Упорным людям однозначно рекомендую.[spoiler]А если у вас ну ооочень слабый компьютер - игра при падении FPS замедляется. От этого только легче[/spoiler]

这将成为我在steam的第一条评论。
说实话，我是冲着军服Sora才买的这个游戏，是的，百分百橙汁里的那个Sora。
看了看游戏视频，发现一个弹幕游戏居然有闪避，于是觉得还是可以玩一玩的便买了下来。（当然还有上面那条原因）
下来之后打开游戏，我靠这简直爽啊。
漂移射击你敢信，射击取消满屏幕乱飞，那个感觉简直爽到。
对玩惯了传统弹幕的我来说真是很新鲜。
不用说，好评。
接下来是一款游戏同样十分重要的部分，剧情与bgm。
剧情十分简单，就是Sora作为个人去阻止世界上那无尽的战争，与各样的人互相碰撞，并且在最后背负了她们的愿望继续下去。
然而搭配boss战中简短的台词以及BGM，使得整体气氛一下子被调动起来。
特别是关卡4的boss战，对阵Sham的bgm更是瞬间加重了悲怆与严肃的氛围。
当其中的人声响起时，Sham所说的那句话，令我至今记忆犹新。
“你很强，Sora，但你是孤独的。”
“这不是像你这样一个人就可以解决的战争。”
让我立刻对这个游戏好感度增倍。
一个麻雀虽小但五脏俱全的游戏，带我感受到了一股最为简单，最为原始的感动。
我觉得这就是一款好游戏所应该具备的素质。

シューティングは苦手ですが、100% Orange Juiceの影響で購入。
キャラ、BGM、ストーリー、どれをとっても素晴らしいゲームだと思います。
ゲーム性はダッシュなどの操作に若干癖があり、難易度も高めですが、壁を乗り越えると最高。
ボスも大技が来るタイミングを調整したり、相性のいい攻撃を選ぶことで、有利に戦えます。
四面からストーリーが大きく盛り上がっていくので、そこまでは挫けないでほしい。
日本語の吹き替えありと表記されていますが、ボイスがあるのは[spoiler]ラスボス[/spoiler]戦のみ。[spoiler] 私VS地球！[/spoiler]

欠点は一部演出が飛ばせないのや日本語非対応なのくらいで、本当に名作です。前作もやりたくなりました。
可愛いキャラや良BGM、シリアスでやりごたえのあるゲームを求める人など広くオススメできます。
実績は簡単でなくとも理不尽に難しい物もなく、クリア後はいい感じの目標になるため全実績を狙う人なんかも。

[h1]Blue Sky Editionについて[/h1]
サントラがセットになっており、個別に買うよりもお得になります。
自分は動画や体験版でBGMが気に入ってたので迷わずセットで買って作業用BGMにしてますが、
よくわからないって人は欲しくなったら個別に買えばいいかと。

30631684.review:
I almost recommend Sora. Almost. The story's great, I love the characters (if not a bit too much), and there's options for which weapons you want to use to bring variety to the game. However...

It's not very fun to play.

It [i]was[/i] fun at first; I accepted how challenging it was. But then, as the game progressed, it just got worse and worse; rather than feeling like a battle of self-improvement to conquer the game, it felt like a constant battle of attrition to just get by. It's very rare for a game to stay in that perfect balance between "Very difficult" and "enjoyable to play". However, it is entirely possible for a game to be extremely difficult yet still feel like an enjoyable experience throughout the entire game; titles like Furi, Risk of Rain, Crypt of the Necrodancer and Hotline Miami did it for me, for example. When playing other "hard" games, it feels like I can always improve upon something, learn from the previous attempt, or at least have some motivation to continue. Sora starts out with those qualities, but loses them as you progress through the game. Whether or not I manage to make it just a bit farther in each level feels like luck more than skill after a while.

Ironically enough, the weapons the game starts you out with are the most viable, and the 'meta' way of playing is to abuse the dash mechanic to maximize DPS while keeping your heat maxed out at 300% (meaning you'll die super fast if you make any mistakes). However, the dash is difficult to control (especially if playing with a controller) and the game's fast-paced enough as-is. Also, ironically, the tutorial hints towards avoiding this kind of play. I think if the game was slowed down just a bit (at least on easy mode), it'd be a lot more enjoyable as you could actually react to the things on screen; that's part of what makes bullet hell games manageable to play.

I did manage to beat the game, but I don't feel very accomplished about it. It wasn't quite a waste of time, but there are far better titles that you can invest your time in to "git gud" at. I'd only recommend this game if you're a masochist, play regular bullet hell games at 1.5x speed, want the 100% Orange Juice DLC character, or a combination thereof.

29251576.review:
Sora is a bullet hell shmup developed by Orange Juice and localized by Fruitbat Factory. The player controls Sora, a girl with extraordinary powers fighting during the time of war, following her desire to protect innocents and once again see the clear sky.

Graphically, the game is... well okay. The backgrounds are generally mostly static and one-color, occassionally giving some actual land to look at, with most of the characters portrayed as sprites, small and sufficient. Portraits during cutscenes do a good job of showing off details and conveying emotions of each character, but that's not much to make up for the rest. The bullets are bright and colorful, just like in most bullet hell shmups, except for live ammo types for obvious reasons.

Sound-design, it's mostly just techno that doesn't stand out. Basic sound effects do what they're supposed to, I guess.

Gameplay-wise, that's where this becomes interesting. The stages have the usual layout of going through a gauntlet of enemies with a midboss in the middle before the end-stage boss. Unlike most standard bullet hell shmups, you get a lot of freedom of movement - Sora possesses a dash ability that lets her jet around and graze beam weapons taking no damage. However it increases her Heat level, which increases damage taken should she get hit before it falls down. Also, besides beam weapons there is live ammo which is slower, but more powerful and ungrazeable via dash. Controlling Sora while she's dashing can be difficult, and it's often easy to, in the heat of battle, just bump into live ammo and suffer a solid amount of damage.
You get to bring three weapons with yourself, two normal ones which can be either beam or live ammo (former being faster, latter being stronger) and one special - a melee weapon of choice, dealing a lot of damage but having short range. Using any of them forces you to stand still for a moment, which leaves you vulnerable to fire. Choosing your time to attack is key to survival.

As much as I'd like to talk about the story, which after the rather amazing intro I feel would be deep and touching, I can't get very far into the game.

This is a major issue with the game, which unfortunately kills the whole experience for me.
This game is hard.

Now I don't have anything against hard games or bullet hell shmups, in fact I've been enjoying [i]Touhou[/i] games for years now, experience with those does not help much in trying to play through Sora. The gameplay is just too different. Still, I see that beating the game on Easy would certainly be possible.

Except it's hard for the [i]wrong[/i] reasons.
No health pickups. No extra lives. No continues.
If you die during a stage, you are kicked back to stage select screen, and you get nothing to your name. Even on Easy, by the time I reach the boss I'm all beat up due to taking damage all throughout and having basically no way to recover it, and I don't get much time to practice the boss' patterns before I inevitably die in a couple hits and have to start over. This is a textbook example of Check Point Starvation aspect of Fake Difficulty right there - the only real way to "save" your progress and refill your health is to beat a stage, and for someone who's just starting out, those stages, especially when you get no health pickups or extra lives whatsoever, are marathons in the war of attrition. Your only real hope of progressing further is to play this game like you're walking on a tightrope, until via sheer trial and error you inevitably get good enough to somehow go through the stage, and then repeat the same process with the next one. This isn't what I would consider fun, especially if a simple addition of health pickups and / or extra lives would eliminate this issue completely.

Can I reccommend this game? Unfortunately no. As much as I wanna see the rest of this story and the game is fun enough, having to play it like a test where less than perfect result means going back to the start of the current stage is too frustrating. Don't bother unless you're alright with repeating the same stage over and over until you finally master it and be able to progress further.

28278600.review:
Sora is a great bullet hell game,

anyone who plays bullet hell games or especially ones from Fruitbat (or Orange Juice) know they can be quite brutal for difficulty, Sora however is a perfect balance. 

After endless struggles with Suguri, i tried sora, not only does the game feel possible but it still stays a challenge, i have only done easy through (bullet hell is the only game i play easy mode, i swear) and it was really tough but possible, a few retries, learning how bosses fight and a hard battle with Hime/Suguri later and i got to see the end game.

For a bullet hell the game it is great, most bullet hell don't have much of a story but Sora does actually, Sora (the ultimate weapon) is fighting alone to put an end to the war, unfortunately not many share her wish, you fight through the bosses to get your wish. The story has some sad moments, especially is you are able sympathise with characters, keeping it spoiler free i will just say i was sad at both my meeting with Sham and the end battle with Star breaker (the ending is great though!) 

The soundtrack is brilliant, i never really buy the ost for games as whilst some are good i feel i will never actually get my money worth but in this case i just kind of wanted the ost, from the great electro background musics to the even vocalled track, i just wanted it. It really is great for creating a setting, the bgm for the stages is commonly quite catchy and works well considering your struggle against the mobs whilst the vocals for the bosses are really mood setting. 

If you enjoy bullet hell games i strongly suggest trying Sora, i enjoyed Suguri and QP shooting dangerous and now can say this takes my favourite of them.

Additionally, if you play 100% Orange juice, you get a free extra character (Sora Military), i brought the game a while back mainly for the character extra (i did plan to play it eventually), but now i know i got a great game and the character extra was a awesome bonus. 

Seriously, it is worth a try if this is your style game. If you aren't into the bullet hell shooters, you might not enjoy this as much as others.

27365581.review:
Star Breaker Did Nothing Wrong.

In all seriousness, the gameplay is very smooth and refined compared to its predecessor, Suguri, consisting of a horizontal shooter where you have to time your shots instead of shooting constantly and where certain bullets can be "dashed" through harmlessly while others will hit you regardless of if you're dashing or not.

The soundtrack is very good, consisting of electronic trance songs that definitely help with immersion. The characters in the game are loveable and have a lot of effort put into them for a bullet hell shooter, and the story can be quite emotional as well. The localisation is on-point and adds a lot of new features, such as the ability to go widescreen without breaking the game. Definitely a lot better than the first localisation…

All in all, one of the best bullet hell shooters of all time, and certainly a unique one compared to Touhou-like shooters. And again, Star Breaker Did Nothing Wrong.

27135101.review:
So, deleted my previous review and writing a new one as I have just recently finished "sora". 
Trying my best to keep it spoiler-free.

==[b] Gameplay [/b]==
The game's a bullet hell, a rather unique one. It's challenging and fun. Some may say it's unfair, but once you get the hang of it, everything becomes a breeze.

You have three weapons at your disposal, the main gun, a secondary and a melee, each weapon does a unique attack whenever you attack after a dash.

There's two unique mechanic that are called Heat Gauge and Dash, the first basically serves as a balance to punish you from getting ahead of yourself with dashing by taking more damage as more heat rises, heat gauge increases from taking damage, dashing and from some certain bosses' attacks.

Dashing is self-explanatory, it's your main ability to dodge and go through enemy's projectiles (That are hopefully not live shells as those will still hit you), however the long you dash the faster your heat gauge rises, controlling this is hard and takes time to get the hang of it's manuevers.

Now, there's two kinds of enemy attacks, a projectile and live shell, the first one you can dash through, the second one you cannot, the former doesn't block your secondary attacks, but the latter can block your secondary and melee attacks. Keep that in mind.

And finally there's this special attacks called Hyper, you have a gauge over on the left side of it, and can hold up to 3 charges, it gets fueled by dashing through enemy attacks and or attacking the enemy themselves. It is very helpful and crucial at times, as it gives you a few second shield that negates any kind of damage. Each weapons has different Hyper attacks, so test them all out to know what to use at the right time.

==[b] Setting [/b]==

Now, the gameplay aspects aside. The setting, story, characters and music are pretty well-done. 
Sora may come off as your generic "wants to save the world"-protagonist, but this is because she doesn't know her purpose but to fight. And as you go through the game she develops more character to reflect on the things she've done and the things she've seen.

The music is trance-melody-ish, a few scores have songs in them which are nice and gives an emotional feeling to it while you listen, it suits and fits the setting of the game and the gameplay of "sora". I'd say it's one of the best underrated soundtracks I've heard in games in my opinion.

==[b] Performance [/b]==

It's a pretty small game, around 500mb download and you can experience good trance bullet hell, it's a 2D side-bullet hell shooter so it shouldn't need that much in terms of system, a laptop can even run it. Just beware that on higher difficulties, means more particles to handle however.
The controls are comfortable, arrow keys for movement, Z for the main gun/confirmation, X for the secondary/cancel, C for Hyper, V for dashing, A for the melee, and S to lock on or disable lock-on/fast forward dialogues. And if you want, you can play it with a controller too!

==[b] Conclusion [/b]==

A nifty underrated gem of a game, "sora" is a must to play even if you are not a fan of bullet hell shooters, the gameplay is fun and challenging, and the story is pretty good. It is the prequel of Suguri [spoiler] also technically the sequel of Suguri due to Stage EX [/spoiler] which means you can play this before playing Suguri, or vice versa.

Now go on and save the world!


That's all! Thank you for reading!

[i] You are the blue of my dreams [i]

26916255.review:
Sora gives the satisfaction of flying around the screen fast to slash your enemies with a sword or shoot them with heavy artillery from point-blank range, all while dashing attacks like mad and listening to fitting nice music. Being a prequel to the first two games in Suguri series, Sora is based on the mechanic of dodging some type of attacks and dashing through other types to absorb them; Sora is probably the best game to start the series due to both the tutorial and an easy difficulty option (which is still pretty hard for a beginner, but doesn't require too many retries to get a feeling of how to play the level right).

The quite engaging plot, which can be summarized as "it's hard to be a beautiful peace-loving girl when you're a flying killer cyborg", allows the game to shift from lighthearted moments to sad and grim ones fast, and we can finally fully understand it, since this is a proper localization.

26897239.review:
Sora is an amazing, fast paced, challenging, shoot 'em up where you play as a girl named Sora (Japanese for "Sky") who was born as the ultimate weapon to fight in a war. 

Let me just skip to the end here and say: Sora is a great game and despite everything I say about it, it is most certainly worth your time, so check it out!

Plot:
******
[spoiler]Sora was born as the ultimate weapon to fight in a war that had been going on for ages. After her first battle in the gloomy, grey sky she glimpses the beautiful blue sky through the clouds before losing consciousness. When she wakes a man tells her of his dream to "clean up the sky" and make the planet a beautiful place to live again. The memory of what Sora saw beyond the grey hued clouds moves her heart and she asks if there is any way she can help. After that she fights a war of protection to defend those who wish to put an end to the war and save the planet from "dying".  [/spoiler]

Gameplay:
************
Sora is a fast paced bullet hell, shoot 'em up and at times can be quite challenging. Sometimes the screen is so filled with projectiles it can be hard to tell where you actually are and where enemies are (especially on higher difficulties). The weapon system is quite good: Beam weapons can be passed through by dashing to charge the hyper gauge and recover health, while "Live-Ammo" projectiles cannot be dashed through, but tend to move slower and do more damage. The dash is also worked into gameplay quite well, allowing quick maneuvers to deal damage without taking to much yourself.

Pros vs. Cons:
****************
Pros:
- Very fun, but still challenging gameplay.
- Amazing story and characters (They will stay with you long after you finish the game).
- Huge variety of weapons and weapon combinations.
- Incredible Soundtrack.
- Different playable modes such as arcade mode (All levels back to back) and match mode (Boss Rush).
- Record you best runs and watch the replays.
- Anime art style.


Cons:
- Story is a little too short and although very good, could have been developed further.
- Some weapons have very limited applications and are never used.
- Replays don't record certain parts of some levels (such as Credits and Cutscenes) meaning you have to replay levels to see them again.
- The game can be brutally difficult at times.
- Voice acting is absent from almost the entire game, except the end of the second-to-last level and the last level making it feel weird and out of place. ([spoiler]It is absent again in the secret "Bonus" level[/spoiler])

Final Words:
**************
As I said at the beginning of this review, Sora is a great game, and is most certainly worth your time. I have had more fun playing Sora than I have in a long time with most other games, and I game alot. If there is one thing to take away from this review make sure it's this: There are far worse uses of your time than Sora!

Very solid sequel. Compared to Suguri, there are 3 weapon slots, stunning visuals, better weapons, great BGM, better boss fights, a proper tutorial, and other cool features like being able to tab out of the game, and being able to regenerate half of the damage taken by charging beam attacks.

That does not mean I do not recommend Suguri however. Both games are fucking awesome and a new touch to the bullet hell genre. Not sure if I even wanna play the typical kind of shmup like Touhou again after this.

If any, the only downsides I find are the general lack of live ammo to punish overheating, and that the gameplay feels a tiny bit slower and easier than Suguri (but nevertheless rage-inducingly difficult).

25974920.review:
A refreshingly challenging shooting game where you assume the role of Sora, a girl who shoulders the mission of protecting nitrogen and oxygen from carbon monoxide and explosive laser beams by shooting more carbon monoxide and explosive laser beams. You'll feel your heartstrings pulled while repeatedly dying in stage after stage as you slowly build the skill and confidence needed to protect the environment from nasty pollutors.

All in all a heartfelt tale about the dangers of environmental destruction. Do recommend.

스팀판이 나오기전에 사서부터 플레이하고 스팀판 나오자마자 바로 구매했습니다.

이전작보다 압도적으로 예쁜 캐릭터 일러스트와 화려한 이펙트, 멋진 3D배경까지 흠잡을데 없이 훌륭합니다. 다만 사양이 좋지않은 컴퓨터에서 몇몇 구간의 이펙트가 게임 속도를 심각하게 저하시키는 문제가 있습니다.

25503172.review:
*LE GASP* How could I have reviewed Suguri but not Sora!? Blasphemy!?

Anyways... Sora, like Suguri, is a bullet hell style shoot 'em up with unique mechanics. We follow our protagonist Sora, a war machine created solely to end said war, fighting back against those who choose to disturb the peace and continue fighting, meeting some familiar faces along the way. The game consists of 7 regular stages and a bonus stage, which may seem small but more than makes up for it in both the difficulty and replayability value.

Sora is in no way as hard as Suguri, however there were some fairly major tweaks in the gameplay to stop the more cheesy strats, such as adding heat penalties for constantly dashing to turn sharply and cancelling delays after shooting. This said, however, the game can be very challenging to those who seek such a challenge with the hard and special difficulties, as well as having a moderate challenge for those like myself who were apparently just never given those bullet hell genes.


The game in general runs smoothly with fairly little lag even on awful laptops such as mine, and the animations are very fluid. The game looks beautiful when we get half a second to look at it, and each little area seems unique, from a snowy alpine region to a barren desert to a gloomy city, never seeming bland or unimaginative to me in the least. The character designs are also very interesting to me, genuinely making me want to get to know these characters more and what caused them to do the things they did.

The game also has it's own little way of teaching you the game mechanics without really teaching you at all. The bosses seem to serve as tutorials, forcing you to get to grips with a certain mechanic and punishing hard if you fail to do so. For example in the first boss battle, the boss uses many fast energy based attacks to force you to learn dashing, whilst the second teaches you how to deal with projectiles that cannot be dashed through and melee attacks. I always find it charming when games like this don't just pop up a little text box, and instead teach you the mechanics through many many tears fighting that one boss over and over until you finally get it... Gotta love it...

The gameplay itself is extremely intuitive, as someone who didn't own a controller for a while, I managed to beat the whole game with keyboard. There aren't a whole lot of buttons to have to learn, there's no having to press 15 buttons at the same time to pull off a super secret special mega ultra attack, just a select few, and that's really all the game needs. The game forces you to make quick decisions but instead of forcing you to fit in a tiny gap between bullets, there are several ways to dodge attacks or beat a boss. The starting weapons are actually pretty good in my opinion, the game doesn't force you to grind in order to get better weapons, instead encourages you to try with what you have, and if that doesn't work, well tough, you just need to get better. By the end of the game, you'll probably have unlocked the majority if not all of the weapons, so it's nice to just go back, play through the stages again and wonder 'what if I used this', or 'what if I did this differently', making the game very enjoyable to play through again.

And if, after playing the game through once, you're thinking 'IF I HAVE TO FIGHT THAT STUPID STAGE 3 MINIBOSS ONE MORE TIME TABLES WILL BE FLIPPED', well you're in luck. The boss battle mode makes for a nice, stressful time, especially on special difficulty, but it's definitely nice to not have to do the whole stage again just to practice the end boss if you're trying on a higher difficulty.

But I mean one good thing in playing the stages over and over and dying over and over is being able to experience the amazing soundtrack Sora has to offer. Honestly in my first playthrough I was too stressed to pay attention, it took a friend pointing out certain tracks for me to realise how wonderful they were, and oh my are they wonderful. After buying the soundtrack I honestly can't name a single track I dislike, even the main menu theme... And that's saying something after you've finished one of the two songs with lyrincs in them, both of which are a nice touch, and not grating as I understand lyrical tracks can be sometimes in games. Honestly I'd buy this game just to listen to the soundtrack, it's just that wonderful.

In conclusion, Sora is a wonderful addition to the bullet hell genre, subverting the norm of 'just shoot and try to fit yourself into these tiny gaps' and improving very much over the original, Suguri, which is also a great game in it's own right. With a great atmosphere, great graphics and a much greater soundtrack, Sora has probably become my favourite bullet hell I've ever played, having probably the 3rd or 4th spot in my favourite OSTs list. I'd recommend buying this dut to all these reasons, and it being fairly cheap certainly helps.

25069393.review:
J'aime ce jeu, vraiment.

Sora c'est l'histoire d'un gros aimant à projectiles aux propriétés extraordinaires lancé dans une folle quête pour sauver un monde mourant en proie à une guerre qui dure depuis longtemps. Avec un gameplay solide et rapide, une bande son qu'il serait criminel de ne pas acheter, une direction artistique agréables et des graphismes faiblards qui ont au moins l'avantage de fournir tout ce qu'il faut d'informations au joueur. Sora est un shooter que je trouve addictif et fun, en plus de disposer d'une pléthore de personnages attachants et d'un lore plus intéressant et complet qu'on ne le pense au départ.

Le finir une fois est difficile si vous avez deux mains gauches comme moi, le jeu vous force à utiliser un système de « dash » permettant de traverser certains projectiles, tout en vous rendant plus vulnérable aux suivants. Vous pouvez ensuite « cancel » les animations d'esquive et de tir et ainsi gagner quelques précieuses frame pour trucider vos adversaires. Si vous souhaitez scorer convenablement, il faudra tuer vos ennemis rapidement (donc prendre des risques) et perdre un minimum de vie (Tout en prenant des risques). Un niveau de Sora réussi c'est un ballet aérien très agréable à l'œil et particulièrement gratifiant dans les plus haut niveau de difficulté.

Vous aimez:
- Les shooter
- Les shooter difficiles
- Sora
- Débloquer des armes, dont beaucoup seront inutiles
- Les bandes sons trance de l'amour
- Les pluies de projectiles qui font mal aux yeux
- Un gameplay complet et très satisfaisant
- Les boss balèzes et charismatiques 
- L'extra stage
- Les jeux correctement localisés et optimisés

Vous n'aimez pas:
- Les jeux ou tout ce qui n'est pas votre incompétence peut vous tuer
- MIRA
- Les jeux sans plusieurs niveaux de difficultés, un mode arcade et un mode donjon SM ou vous pouvez vous mesurer aux boss
- Les jeux sans high score ni moyen de les conserver pour les regarder plus tard
- Les jeux avec voice acting, sauf sur un boss.. Pendant deux lignes de dialogues
- Les jeux qui ne vous font pas « allez, encore une dernière » après un échec cuisant

Qu'est ce que vous attendez?  [i]« Make the entire sky blue! »[/i]

Alright.. for a 2hu vetern.. this is still way harder then expected....

Mainly because most weapon you can only shoot them without moving around and thus making shooting/evading a lot harder since most of the weapon shoot on a 0.5 second timer and a game like this.. a lot can happen in half a second. 

The game itself is quite short.. 1 training level .. 1 extra level and 7 regular stage level that tells the story of our favorite living weapon in 100% OJ universe.. Sora... (well.. Sora > Suguri)... She was build by Sham's team as the greatest weapon they have to win the war and stop the war yet this all Sora want to do is fight to protect... Music is very amazing. combat animation is awesome and bullet pattern is patterned within chaos as long as you learn them. Some of the in game achievements are quite crazy that involve defeating boss in a certain way....

24614283.review:
Sora ist ein horizontaler Shoot ‘em Up von OrangeJuice, den Machern von Spielen wie „QP Shooting – Dangerous“ und „100% Orange Juice“ (welches früher oder später wohl auch eine Rezension von mir erhalten wird).
Dieses Spiel ist ein Teil der Suguri Reihe und erzählt die Geschehnisse vor dem ersten Suguri Spiel. Die Originale Version von Sora erschien 2010, wobei eine verbesserte HD Version von Sora Januar 2016 auf Steam erschienen ist.

[h1]Handlung[/h1]
Die Welt ist zerrüttet von Krieg. Menschen bekämpfen sich seit Ewigkeiten gegeneinander, solange schon, dass niemand überhaupt mehr die Ursache des Krieges kennt. Eines jedoch ist gewiss: keine der beiden Seiten wird sich die Blöße geben und den Kampf ohne Sieg beenden.
Somit kommt Sora ins Spiel. Ihr Körper konnte auf eine besondere Weiße verstärkt werden, wodurch sie den Sieg in diesem Krieg erbringen soll. Nun ist es Soras Aufgabe, ihrer Bestimmung zu folgen, ob sie es will, oder nicht.

Da dieses Spiel ein Shoot ‘em Up ist, ist die Handlung nicht besonders tief; am Ende jedes Levels trifft man auf einen Boss Charakter, es werden ein paar Worte ausgetauscht, und schon folgt ein Kampf. Aber trotzdem schafft das Spiel es, einige wiedererkennbare und sympathische Charaktere zu schaffen, und am Ende des Spiels hofft man, dass Sora ein gutes Ende für ihre Welt herbeibringen kann. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Sora ist ein horizontaler Shoot ‘em Up des Bullet Hell Subgenres. Jedoch anstatt sich hauptsächlich auf das Ausweichen von Projektilen zu konzentrieren, besitzt Sora, so wie die Vorgängerspiele in der Suguri-Reihe, einen großen Fokus auf das Timing von Angriffen.
Im Gegensatz zu anderen Shoot ‘em Ups kann man in Sora nicht einfach dauerhaft Projektile auf Gegner feuern, da Sora bei jedem Schuss auf ihrer derzeitigen Position stehen bleibt und somit ein leichtes Ziel für gegnerische Projektile wird.

Es gibt drei Arten von Projektilen: 
• Laser, welche in der Regel schnell gefeuert werden können, jedoch weniger Schaden machen und, sofern sie von den Gegnern kommen, von Sora mithilfe der Dash-Fähigkeit unbeschadet durchquert werden können, 
• ballistische Projektile, wie Raketen, welche am meisten Schaden machen, dafür Sora aber länger am Platz halten, und 
• Nahkampfwaffen, welche Sora zwingen, nahe an die Gegner und somit an unerwarteten Projektile heranzurücken.
Somit sind nicht nur Reflexe und Einprägung der Geschossmuster die einzigen Gewinnfaktoren, sondern auch der richtige Einsatz der Waffen, was das Spiel so besonders macht.
Sora kann zu jeder Zeit eine Waffe jedes Waffentyps besitzen, wobei weitere Waffen dieser Typen im Laufe des Spiels freigeschaltet werden können, um dem Spieler mehr Individualisierungsmöglichkeiten zu geben. Man kann das Spiel aber auch sehr gut mit den Standardwaffen durchspielen, welche sogar meine persönlichen Lieblingswaffen sind.

Jedes Level besitzt zwei Teile: Im ersten kämpft man gegen eine Reihe von verschiedenen kleineren Gegnern, und im zweiten Teil bekämpft man einen dreiphasigen Boss.
Im ersten Teil des Levels wird ein großer Fokus darauf gelegt, herauszufinden, welche Waffe am besten bei welchem Gegner wirkt, während bei den Bosskämpfen eher das traditionelle Ausweichen von Projektilen im Fokus steht, wodurch, bei den gleichen Spielmechaniken, ein Wandel der benötigten Fähigkeiten stattfindet, was das Spiel interessant hält, selbst wenn man nur ein Level am Stück spielt.

Sora ist recht herausfordernd, selbst auf der einfachsten Schwierigkeitsstufe, und das auch für Shoot ‘em Up Fans. Sobald man sich aber an die Waffenmechanik gewöhnt hat, wird das Spiel wesentlich einfacher.

[h1]Präsentation[/h1]
Das Spiel verwendet einen Mix aus 2D Sprites für die Charaktere und Objekte, und 3D Hintergrundgrafiken, und ist in einem Anime-haften Kunststil gehalten. Alles in allem sieht das Spiel ganz gut aus.
Wer hofft, in diesem Spiel schöne Projektilmuster (wie z.B. in den Touhou Spielen) zu sehen, wird leider enttäuscht werden. Dieses Spiel ist generell nicht so farbenfroh wie man es von Anime Shoot ‘em Ups erwarten könnte. Dafür gibt es aber einige gute Lichteffekte, die etwas mehr Kontrast in das Spiel bringen.
Was Sora an Farbe fehlt, gleicht es mit einem überaus mitreißenden Trance-Soundtrack wieder aus. Die Lieder passen sehr gut zu diesem Spiel, und obwohl ich Trance eher weniger mag, bin ich trotzdem richtig begeistert von dem Soundtrack. 
Der OST kann im Bundle zusammen mit dem Spiel (oder auch separat als DLC) gekauft werden.


[h1]Fazit[/h1]
Sora ist ein sehr gutes Shoot ‘em Up Spiel mit einer etwas anderen, aber bei weitem nicht schlechten Spielmechanik. Fans von (Anime) Shoot ‘em Ups sollten sich dieses Spiel auf jeden Fall holen.
Für Personen, die keine Spiele mögen, bei denen man sehr schnelle Reflexe benötigt, sollten jedoch lieber die Finger von diesem Spiel lassen.

Sora bekommt von mir 4 von 5 Orangen.

I've bought this game because I had cash to spend and I kind of wanted the Military Sora costume, I told myself ''Why waste a perfectly good game'' so i played it.
Oh boy did I not expect such a difficult game...

The game plays great, controls are great and if you don't like the original layout, you can change it, the story, even though at the time of this review I've yet to beat the first level, seem rather interesting and overall the game looks great and has a solid framerate with the exception of you using your quite flashy special attacks.

If I do have one gripe with the game, it's the difficulty, which, if you aren't 100% in the game with great reflexes, you aren't going to get past the first level easily, however the deaths are always on the player's hands, there are more times then one that I ended up dashing right into missiles without noticing my health, trying to get the meter up and being over all, reckless, which I still learned from.

TL;DR The game's hard, controls are responsive and it's the player's fault for any deaths, recomended for sure

高機動アクションシューティングゲー。

見た目の印象は弾幕シューティングっぽいけど、
実際のプレイ感覚はむしろアクションゲームに近い。

弾幕シューティングのように繊細な操作で避けて撃つのではなく、
特殊動作のダッシュで大まかに敵弾をくぐり抜けてズバッと倒す、
そんな感じ。

ダッシュを駆使した高速戦闘は慣れるまで苦労するけど、
乗り越えられれば脳汁出まくりの世界がそこに。

激しい弾幕をダッシュですいすい抜けながらザコを次々と叩き落とし、
ボスと華麗な空中戦を繰り広げるこのスピード感と高揚感は、
他のゲームでは味わえない魅力。


難易度は高いもののいわゆる覚えゲーなので、
繰り返しプレイすることで少しずつ先に進めるようになっていく。

コツコツ上達する過程を楽しめる人で、
他にはない魅力を持ったアクション系ゲームをやりたいなら強くおすすめ。


ゲームにマッチしたトランス系のBGMや、
シンプルだけど重く、それでいて爽やかな幕引きのストーリーも好みだった。
とても良いゲームだと思う。あとソラすごくかわいい。

整体来说上手后难度并没有想象中那么高

--------------------------------------------

要点：不要随意冲刺
冲刺能擦弹，也能回红的血槽，但副作用是提升HEAT槽，而冲刺时的速度通常很快从而导致难以控制，此时撞上实弹或者攻击中断冲刺时撞上激光弹都会非常疼，实际上很多时候并非是需要无脑冲刺才能解决的，多观察、冷静走位，其实也能化解很多攻击
冲刺攻击也不要随便乱用，理由同上

要点2：肉搏战
有的BOSS由于近身弹幕太密集或者难以miss（PS：3面的BOSS）而只能游走激光打，不过大部分BOSS都能贴身换血砍。近战攻击带有短时间无敌，且由于未冲刺从而使得HEAT很低，即使受伤也通常不会掉太多血

--------------------------------------------

个人使用的武器搭配：

Main：Rifle-M（初期武器，性能平均）
Sub：ARTILLERY（需要入手，前方随机多道激光，对付实弹系弹幕的首选，对于判定大的BOSS贴身打也有奇效）
Special：Sword（初期肉搏武器，攻高带无敌判定，谁用谁知道）

--------------------------------------------

最后补上通关后ソラ的一句话吧

「空　綺麗になるかなぁ」ーーソラ

--------------------------------------------

关于EX（EASY难度打了4个小时233）

EX连战Hime和Suguri两个（战Suguri的血条直接继承战完Hime后的），所以打Hime需要尽量减少受伤

Hime的弹幕中，蓝色子弹/激光和锁链无法擦弹，记住这点后全程冲刺擦弹然后找机会黑枪，慢慢磨吧

别试图拼近战，会被Hime的弹幕打成筛子（所以我打了4个小时233）

如成就所言，两个舞者之间的PK

打Suguri难度要小得多，飞行格斗，擦弹、躲实弹、黑枪、小心大招，然后慢慢打吧，不玩脱的话基本上都能干掉

PS：打两人的时候，尽量不要回头冲刺，很可能撞上实弹弹幕（真的勇士从不回头看爆炸233）

First off let me say I REALLY wanted to like this game. On the surface I loved the look of this game and I love me some anime stuff as much as the next guy. Call me dumb but i partially bought this game for the story (probably a mistake) but also you know, I have played a few of this shoot 'em up like games (well maybe only one I can remember) but still I really wanted to see what this game was like.

So... I play the tutorial, okay seems striaghtforward enough, after that I am flung into what i assume is level one after some cut scenes backstory etc.,a and I manage to scrape my way through level 1 (I think?) which its fair im just picking this up I dont expect to master this game in 10 minutes, but hey at least I am progressing. After that im sent back to the now existant start menu after another little cutscene. Okay! i guess this means I can continue the story so i go to story mode, only to find the only levels I can play are the tutorial and the level I JUST BEAT. I then Think to myself alright maybe I just gotta beat this level once more to get this rolling.

 I load it up it asks for difficulty level I think okay, Normal seems like a fair place even though it states its for people who are "used to the game"  whatever that means? Well that is where the fun stops the level I just beat, cant beat it again... I tried at least 8 times or so and COULD NOT even get close to beating it. I really believe in a challenging games but playing the first level over and over and over again just aint fun. It is honestly quite demoralizing I am I terrible at this game or something?

23205641.review:
[h1]= Forward =[/h1]

Before I get to the review I will admittedly say that I pre-ordered this game and it's soundtrack on the premise of getting the free character "Sora (Military)" for "100% Orange Juice" and to just have some extra music to listen to.

I booted the game up just over 6 months (yesterday) after it's release on a whim to see if it would provide a good break from the usual titles I had been playing and it instantly became a title I'm going to remember for a long time.

[h1]= Review =[/h1]

- Initial experience with gameplay -

It's been about a year since I last played a bullet hell shooter so I was basically coming in as good as the general noob and I have to say it was an interesting experience to get thrashed as hard as I did on easy.

11 hours in and I finaly beat easy (minus the extra and boss rush) but I realised something as I went through the story mode.

Much like 'getting good' in the popular "Dark Souls" I stopped over analyzing things and began the trend of analyzing how I died and then remembered what caught me off guard.

The game had soon turned from a screen filled torrent of death to an intricate maze of paterns.

I realize that this is common hat for the geanre but I found "Sora" more forgiving than other giants such as "Touhou" and more challenging than something like "Trouble Witches NEO".

It was refreshing to know that I was able to grasp victory eventually.

The boss that gave me the biggest headache to beat was Lv 3's boss with 28 attempts to show how terrible I was at the beginning.

Every other boss in the game thus far for me has been under 10 attempts.

- Gameplay Features -

Another interesting facet that I found in this game that I hadn't seen before was the Dash/Heat feature and the Weapon System.

The Dash and Heat features in the game provide a nice ease of use and risk/reward set-up. where dashing lets you pass through 80% of the attacks comming at you but using it increases the damage you take coming out of it.

It was an interesting mechanic that let my noob self get accustomed to the enemies and my skilled self work on getting the fastest times possible with not a single hit. 

With the weapon set-up the game outright presented itself as one who can be solved with no one key combination.

I found myself experimenting with different weapons to see how I could manage the levels and while I can say I royally flopped with some I can clearly see their usefullness to some one more skilled or of a different mind-set.

I would also like to note that almost all the weapons are unlocked on attempt count wrather than level completion count.

That alone let me quickly adapt and grow with the weapons that I loved and compare them with other unique weapons.

Which is great for people who are wanting to experiment early on or are frustrated with certain bosses.

- Presentation -

I decided to read up on the development blog post made by the devs at Orange Juice and I have to say I appreciate everything that this game is asthetically.

Everything about the geanre of Danmaku and Bullet Hells is supposed to feel nostalgic no mater the rendering.

Like an old arcade title you toss coins into, this game has out-and-in gameplay done wonderfully.

I can count at most 6 seconds going from a death anywhere in the game to booting the level back up and beginning my next attempt. 

- Characters and Story -

I've played both 100% Orange Juice and 200% Mixed Juice extensively so I've always wondered what the character's source material from all the OJ games were about.

I was surprised that Sora's story was as interesting as it was.

There isn't much dialouge in the game and only a couple of scenes are voiced but the dialouge that does happen gives all the info you need on the characters and the conflict.

The dialouge is a little rough on the translation side and the wording is quite simple but I will say that I found the story quite gripping despite that.

- Visual Asthetics -

The're is an odd simplicity to the graphics and yet the high resolution brings out so much in it's environment.

The levels and stages were quite stunning to have as backdrops to the on screen action as the break-up points in combat always lead to some sort of transformation in the background to warn you of the imposing doom or to show your movement through the world.

The Menu and UI are also clean and crisp to give a perfect ci-fi tone.

I believe it's one of the best I've seen.

- Audio -

The game has a stunning Trance soundtrack that I'm happy was released for sale.

The high speed and mixture of light and dark atmospheres in the game are perfectly matched to the level themes.

Two of the boss songs even have vocal which caught me off guard.

[h1]= The Final Verdict =[/h1]

While my play time hasn't been massive as of now I know quite well it will be.

This game has instantly gripped me both in it's asthetic and wildly fun gameplay that is more immediately forgiving than other bigger bullet hell series.

It invoked nostalgia in me even though I'm someone who has not played a lot of this geanre and generally unfamilliar with the developers material.

The big thing that made me fall in love with the game was it's match of visual and sound.

I will be looking to this game if anyone ever asks me what an asthetically correct game looks like.

I'm dissapointed in myself for not trying this game sooner and will be brushing off the dust on un-played titles more often.

I will ultimately give this game a [b]9 / 10[/b] for it's approachability and solid design as the dialouge is really the only big flaw I can give it.

Thanks Orange Juice and Fruite Bat Factory for this title that will inspire my own game design.

22423987.review:
Where to even begin?  The gameplay is phenomenal.  A worthy successor to Suguri for sure.  It really feels like they took everything great about Suguri and polished it to perfection.  The game is fast and very challenging.  It demands your full attention; blinking can be the difference between life and death.  There were numerous times where I simply had to keep my eyes open for as long as I could.  The game looks beautiful.  The story isn't overly complicated and is nice and simple.  However, it has a hook that keeps you invested.  The world is gloomy and in a dire state.  This is reflected by Sora's internal struggle and her longing to help.  Ending up empathizing with Sora is easy to do as you progress through her trials.

The soundtrack is beautiful.  It compliments the gameplay and the setting perfectly.  Love this game, and I'd recommend it to anyone, especially those looking for a real challenge.

21399353.review:
(This review is negative, but only just. I really hate Steam's binary rating system.)

For more reviews, and a short gameplay video, check out probablysanny.wordpress.com !

I was quickly frustrated when I started playing Sora. The game isn't unfair, it just does an incredibly poor job of communicating it's boss mechanics. You'll have no idea what you're supposed to be doing the first time in a fight, maybe even the second and third. Sora expects you to figure things out on your own, which can be extremely frustrating. If you're interested in playing this game, I suggest patience. If you persist, it's quite enjoyable.

Unlike other shmups, in Sora, you can't just hold down the fire button. When you attack, you are forced to stand still for a brief period, and are left vulnerable. You can cancel out of these attacks, but I found the sudden change in momentum jarring at first. It takes a while to get used to if you've played other shmups before. But, I think this unique mechanic is the only real edge Sora has.

You can equip 3 weapons before each stage. Generally, a rifle, a rocket and a melee weapon, although there are some exceptions, such as mines. The melee weapons are very high risk/reward and add a bit more variety to the combat.

I'm not a big fan of Sora's artstyle, but it isn't objectively bad. I think the hand-drawn characters have a certain cute charm to them, even if I don't really appreciate it. However, The combination of the playable character and bosses as 2-D sprites with the 3-D enemies and backgrounds certainly put me off. They don't feel like they belong in the same game, but the problem is mostly ignorable after the first few minutes of gameplay.

The music isn't as great as other soundtracks I've heard recently, but I still enjoyed it. I especially liked the track that plays in Stage 7, however ironically. The Engrish vocals are just too good for me to ignore, I smile every time.

Sora lacks an overall level of polish. The visuals look a bit off, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it should be, and there are a lot strange design choices. I have no idea how the weapon unlock system works, they seem to randomly appear after stages every now and then, regardless of how well I performed. Is it simply tied to how many stages I've played? Are there secret tasks you have to perform? I have no idea.

I don't think Sora is a brilliant example of bullet-hells, and I don't feel like I'm really in the intended audience, but I still had a lot of fun with it. It's interesting enough to set it apart from it's competition, so if you're really itching for something new, I'd recommend picking it up. There are probably better options out there to sate your bullet-hell fix, but I wouldn't ignore Sora entirely.

20689165.review:
Sham is a cutie <3

Bullet hells are typically fairly formulaic in fashion, mostly being based around pure dodging in a vertically-oriented screen space with focused movement, small hitboxes allowing for grazing and oftentimes you have your standard bullet-cancelling scoring tricks. Orange Juice had subverted most of these tropes in Suguri, and continue to polish their style of danmaku gameplay in the sequel Sora.

The main nuance to this series is that instead of the standard focused movement, you can perform a dash that sends you flying quickly across the screen. This dash allows you to phase through bullets and standard lasers, but you are still susceptible to physical obstacles such as rockets, dashing also builds up your heat gauge which makes you take even more damage (up to 3 times more damage at 300%). This along with the dashing being used to cancel out shot inputs makes most of the depth in this game, as fighting becomes a visceral mix of shooting and dashing around enemy bullets and rockets, as you try to destroy everything as fast as possible. The potential of these mechanics are realized as each boss plays differently and demand different skills and understanding of mechanics from the player. For example, Tsih can temporarily go invisible meaning that you cannot lock-on to them during this time and you will have to use melee attacks against them, whereas Sham surrounds you with smaller swarming enemies which require switching your lock-on frequently.

Although you can phase through most projectiles, this game is in no way easy. If you are new or relatively new to the series like I was when starting this game, it will take you a while to get used to the fast pace of enemy attacks and the sheer density of projectiles at certain points. The game has quite a steep learning curve that will challenge those experienced with bullet hells along with a grading system at the end of each stage which makes the act of playing Sora feel rewarding and addictive. 

Like its predecessor, Sora oftentimes feels like a blend between a fighting game and a shmup, especially due to the addition of swords and other melee weapons that you can use. The scoring system capitalises on this, as it rewards players who can play aggressively and take out hordes of enemies swiftly without taking damage. The addictive mechanics are topped off with an improved visual presentation from Suguri and a great trance-style soundtrack that succeeds in giving each boss a lasting impression.

All in all, Sora feels like an ideal sequel to suguri, as it further expands on the innovations made by suguri with new weapons, abilities, boss fights and certain balance changes. If you are at all a fan of the doujin circle Orange_Juice you would be doing yourself a great disservice by missing out on Sora.

20670402.review:
I honestly never would have thought this game would come to steam.

This game, Sora, is the sequel to the game Suguri, which was published by Rockin' Android. You are Sora, an enhanced, basically mechanized superhuman fighting in a neverending war that seems to encompass all of Earth, and your goal is to make people stop fighting... by shooting rockets into their faces. Nobody said peacekeeping was easy!

Anyway, this is actually the second time the game has been localized. The first time was done by--I guess you can call them a person--called OmegaTH, who, bluntly speaking, screwed the pooch in localizing it. Horrific translations, Pointless name changes, terrible bugs, missing music I believe, game breaking DRM, the improper use of the word "Reploid" were just a few of the things that you could have expected from that localization. 

It seemed the game was doomed to be stuck in a kind of limbo where it was basically as good as never released in the US. 

At least until Fruitbat factory came outta nowhere and decided through the darkest of magic rituals to obtain the license to the game and give it the release it deserved.

The game has none of the aforementioned problems of the previous localization, integrates with the steam overlay without any flaws, seems to control flawlessly (I've read it "feels" off compared to the Japanese version, though I cannot confirm that), and just exudes a lot of the love and care put into it to make it a fine release. The only minor flaw I could think of is some slowdown during the more intense bossfights, though there are options to remove blur effects and the likes to mitigate it. Aside from that the game is as good as it can get.

They did the impossible [strike]saw the invisible[/strike] and should have the highest praise from everyone for just going where I would figure no one else would try to do. 

Anyway, it's an awesome game that anyone who is a fan of great shmups,  good video game music, or just anyone looking for a fun challenge, should pick up.

20521587.review:
So I've poured in 25 Hours into Sora and I'm 3 achievement's away from having them all (Though I might have them all y the time you read this *or not*) and so I can hopefully pass on my opinion.

Story
--------
You are Sora, a human who has been modified to fly and fight and is given a blaster, bazooka, and energy sword at the start of the mission but will get some as you progress *or die*. The people on earth have been fighting with each other for whatever reason. So basically you are a war asset and other things which I won't mention due to spoilers.

Gameplay
--------------
The game is very very challenging. It's not as difficult as Suguri (The first game, Sora is the Prequel) but still not that easy. Mission 1 took me 1 try, Mission 2 took me 2 tries but Mission 3... Took me 15 and the scale gets higher until I reached Mission 5 Where I beat it on my first but the rest soon took longer to finish. So yeah, not too easy and not too difficult but for most I think they'd say its hard. Enough about difficulty, tiem for the gametype, It's a Bullet-Hell. But instead of moving around the energy bullets you can pass through them if you were to Use your "Dash" ability. However, you cannot dash through live ammunition (Eg. Missiles) and as you dash, you gain Heat. Heat can reach up to 300% and that would mean if you were to get hit... You will take much more damage. Heat would take about 8 seconds to settle *But you need to keep dodging too* so it's really bad if you are careless.In each mission, there are enemies which pop up throughout the mission (henchmen?), followed by a mid-stage boss which is there to prepare you for the true boss and at the end, the actual boss with a name and health bar. As I said before, You unlock even more weapons as you progress so you can ditch your sword for an even bigger sword *After dying 100 Times* I really like arcade games so this was a treat for me. If you don't like Bullet-hell games then you should just ignore this game.

Art
-----
Sora is such a freakin adorable character <3 (and some others too but no one can beat Sora imo)
The character sprites are really well done and pretty (Atleast to my taste). The level design is like it's from a ps2 era game so nothing special. The missiles and lasers you blast out (and or shot at you) are also well animated which givest he game more life. 

That's about the only thing I can think to describe this nice and wonderful game. I hope they make a 3rd Installment to the story.

My Overall score for Sora: 8.5/10 considering the price and maybe because I'm biased.

20519105.review:
Plays pretty similar to its predecessor, Suguri, being that you move horizontally and use your dash to phase through energy based attacks, while shooting enemies. So gameplay wise, if you enjoyed Suguri you'll definitely like Sora, especially with the latter's refinements over the original. For example, dash spamming has been nerfed in general--initiating a dash will boost your Heat by about 30%, thus making it more risky to turn on a dime. You also gain Heat from attack cancelling, making that riskier as well. The difficulty curve also feels less abrupt than in Suguri (I still have PTSD from that Kae fight), and scales more linearly. Furthermore, the weapons have been rebalanced making most of the worse weapons from Suguri more viable.

In terms of length, it took me around 9 hours or so to beat story mode (stages 1-7) on easy, so there's quite a bit of content, along with the fantastic OST. Even if you're not so good at these games like I am, you should be able to progress atleast on easy.

20515876.review:
给和我一样因为N卡双显卡笔记本打Hime的时候游戏变慢而困扰的同学。
参考自 http://steamcommunity.com/app/390730/discussions/0/405692758710895087/

游戏变慢（这不是为了方便手残玩家的故意设定）是因为Sora是使用 DirectX 8 来运行的，而N卡双显卡切换需要 DirectX 9 以上的程序，所以对于双显卡的电脑来说这个游戏只能使用集显运行。而集显的性能不足导致了游戏速度变慢。

首先你需要去Nvidia控制面板 - 管理3D设置 - 程序设置 - 选择要自定义的程序 里找出Sora的运行程序“sora.exe”。
之后在 为此程序选择首选图形处理器 中下拉选择“高性能NVIDIA处理器”。
接下来下载 DX8 to DX9 程序 http://enbdev.com/convertor_dx8_dx9_v0014.htm 或者从这里下载 http://pan.baidu.com/s/1hsDGKCk 。
解压，把解压出来的4个文件拷贝到Sora游戏的安装目录下。
运行游戏，即可让游戏以Nvidia显卡运行，改善迟缓现象。如果仍然卡顿，请尝试在游戏设置中关闭“Blur Effects”选项。

经过我的笔记本 Intel HD 4600 + Nvidia GTX 960M 的测试，在不进行上述更改的情况下，EX关卡在Hime发Hyper的时候非常慢。在进行上述更改的情况下，打开“Blur Effects”时，特定Boss放大的时候会出现一时的卡顿，在进行上述更改的情况下，关闭“Blur Effects”时，暂时没有遇见任何卡顿的情况。

————以下是旧评论————
游戏本身很好玩，很刺激。很有挑战性（对于我这种手残）。
可是steam版的在后面几个关卡boss战，尤其是ex关降速非常严重（确定不是为了让你更方便躲弹幕吗）。
日版的没有这个问题，好好学日语去玩日版吧www
推荐这个游戏，但是不推荐玩steam版

20459181.review:
Altamente recomendado! Principalmente se você for fan dos jogos da [url=http://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Orange_Juice&snr=1_5_9__408]Orange Juice[/url], assim como fanático pelos gêneros de Bullet Hell e Shoot´Em Up.

[H1]*História:[/H1]

Não tenho muito a dizer, pois joguei muito pouco, mas é algo parecido com um outro jogo da série chamado [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/262240]Suguri[/url] (editado por empresas diferentes), aonde os inimigos atiram e aparecem de lado, vim tratar a respeito disso de todas as formas....

[H1]História de desenvolvimento:[/H1]

SORA, tem uma história não muito legal de uns tempos atrás. Pelo que ouvi boatos ele foi trazido para a América por uma empresa que tinha uma baixa reputação e conclusão, o jogo foi abandonado da história e mal traduzido, como controles de baixa qualidade. Essa empresa nem existe nada e provavelmente ficará extinta na história.

Felizmente, para a nossa felicidade chegou uma outra chamada [url=http://fruitbatfactory.com]"Fruitbat Factory"[/url], aonde o primeiro jogo trazido para a Steam foi [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/282800]100% Orange Juice[/url] (Também disponível na Steam). Em primeira mão eu joguei aquele jogo de tabuleiro, mais por não ter um jogo como aquele na minha biblioteca, mas rapidamente eu amei com relação a jogabilidade, ao mesmo tempo que detestava em algumas partes.

Com o decorrer do tempo, a [url=http://fruitbatfactory.com]"Fruitbat Factory"[/url] foi atualizando o jogo até ser possível colocar em resoluções mais altas, como também foi criando sistemas anticheat, adicionando novas personalizações nos personagens, colocando níveis de dificuldade, enfim foi deixando o jogo cada vez melhor. Hoje o jogo está muito bem trabalhado, até com relação a DLCs o preço delas é razoavelmente barato também, comparado a outros jogos.

Citei o exemplo do jogo acima, apenas para falar que é uma empresa realmente comprometida com o que faz e deixa seus jogos de uma forma perfeita, para que os jogadores possam aproveitar a essência daqueles jogos...

SORA é mais um exemplo deles, o jogo originalmente não havia resolução em HD e os controles de um Xbox 360 nem era possível, mas o jogo tem tudo isso além de algumas coisas a mais...

[H1]*O jogo em si:[/H1]

Ele está totalmente em HD, os controles (em teclado) são totalmente fluentes, é possível mudar resolução e controles dentro do jogo em si, além das músicas serem extremamente legais e emocionantes o que é equilibrado a um toque de dificuldade... Para maiores informações de como foi o desenvolvimento do jogo, deixo o link abaixo para algumas informações. [B]SOMENTE EM INGLÊS[/B]

http://blog.fruitbatfactory.com/2016/01/10/sora-a-development-story

Nota: 9/10

20422816.review:
Fun game 
Definately a good game to play if you're chilling and just wana shoot stuff XD

What I hate about the game?

If I had to critticize this game on anything its probably on just the way the mechanics are
There are a lot of dumb features in the game that accomplish nothing but raise an eyebrow.
The weapon design trifecta is incredibly arbitrary and at some points very two faced

So the design is supposed to be that you can:
Dash < Beam Attacks
Dodge or Destroy < Missile Projectiles
And your melee is just a melee

This annoys me on so many levels.
The training stage establishes this idea where the level/power of your beam attack holds a vital role in either over-riding other attacks or simply destroying their projectiles

Not only is it incredibly aggrevating trying to attack missiles with beam attacks to destroy their projects but you cannot target them. Which makes destroying projectiles guessing games at best.
Beam attacks are stupidly random, where certain beam attacks cannot be dashed past, but then they teach you you're supposed to dash vs beam attacks? Why even...?

Melee weapons are incredibly useless, their damage is laughable at best and only promote the idea of staying long range and keeping the highest priority to dodge stuff.
There's no reward for being risky with a melee weapon, and in various instances beam weapons seem to easily outdps projectile and melee attacks.

There are no base attack values or any form of attack damage calculations or functions which teach you in the game and makes the training stages tips about knowing the damage you inflict with weapons completely negligible 

Beam attacks have a very... VERY slow rate of fire and usually promote animation cancelling as a way of life, instead of a quirky reward for being quick on controls.

Rocket Launchers are the same thing, however you're also inclined to suffer through their poor projectile speed which is so lazy any idea of even thinking their a threat to dodge is a joke. It makes the idea of simply destroying the projectiles as a strategy of minimizing threat a smart idea, but without any form of control/targetting onto missiles, the idea is hastily culled.

The last thing I want to mention is the boss design. They're all the same
They all have this rather lazy blink around, "ha you cant target me! wait until my boring invicibility frame has ended while I charge my ultimate attack!?!"
And well... it's pretty dull XD
Though it doesn't really impede on the game THAT much... the strategies used to fight bosses only differ around the idea of survivability which is one thing I do like. However the blink factor is hella annoying!
The other thing I don't like is that there are no... not so obvious weaknesses from bosses that you can exploit or use as a way to optimize the boss fight for fast times and quickest possible kills
It's just, shoot, dodge their stuff, shoot again.  The weapons you acquire don't give you a dynamic advantage against bosses or enemies... they're just weapons.
If there was weaknesses, resistances which punish you for your weapon choices and demand you change things around, where you have to use your melee, missile or beam attacks specifically. This would be an awesome touch to the game!

If I had to suggest any solution to the above, i'd state the following:
1) Make missile projectiles much faster, so dodging them is an actual challenge.
This works both ways, for Sora's attacks and for enemy attacks.

2) Either nerf beam attack power and increase their rate of fire. Or set a more dynamic difference between beam and missile attacks. Missiles either have the faster rate of fire but with projectile travel distance & time in mind.
Or make beam attack rates faster and make beams designed to be weak & fast for rapid fire design or design beam rifles so you can fire and move simutaneously with weaker damage and more heat gain

3) Make melees stronger and more dynamic,
There needs to be a substancial reward in going close range. Especially when 99% of enemies simutaneously fire missiles and beam attacks at the same time.
Also design SOME melee enemies. To create more unpredictability and interesting encounters, it doesn't do justice when every boss attacks that fall under the condition of "Melee" are all long range attacks that you're just forced to dodge and survive from

4) Animation cancelling should not be a necessity
This kind of annoys me but at the same time, it's a live and learn kind of thing.
I just think the game design makes you rely heavily on the idea of this mechanic, and in some places would be hilarious if they made a boss where it punishes you for doing it, instead of just a bucket of rewards, and your only route to fast rate of fire.

5) Make bosses physically move around, instead of blinking lazily to 1 corner of the screen
The bosses are incredibly immobile, and half the time the blink function that they use simply makes the boss fight tedious instead of challenging.
when they're stationary for such a long time before they blink, it makes targetting/attacking them so easy, and it forces a routine of simply shoot, dodge, shoot dodge. 
Perhaps things will get harder in a sequel or something, but i think its worth considering.

What I love about this game?

It's simple for starters, and that's something I appreciate!
I'm tired of all these graphic whores of games where it's so easy to just read where the majority of development spent there time.
This game is easy on the eyes, with a niche anime touch to it, which actually makes it pleasant to look at, instead of eye blinding.

Trial and error feel
I love this a lot! Theres a trial and error theme to this game, where perfection is the main objective.
Trying to complete a level without taking damage is a hell of a fun challenge which demands a good memory, reactions and a strong learning attitude.
If you're into games with trial and error factors, this game will definately be a good one for you

Sora is adorable
Nuff sed! I want Sora plush-dolls <3

Decent weapon variety
Ok i'll admit I'm kind of on the fence with this one. And this is probably a major point which mitigates my rant about the weapon designs.
The weapon variety is cool. don't get me wrong. and its nice to have a lot of stuff to try out, and a slight explorational grind where completing one level multiple times in hopes for more weapons is a viable thing to do.
But it's the base design of the weapons which I feel makes it suck. They all have the same weaknesses. And the enemies dont exploits the weapon flaws in ways you can, which makes for a rather linear experience.

Stages are short and sweet, but full of action
There's rarely a dull moment during a stage, especially if you run with arcade mode.
It has a great flow to it, and it's very smooth with nice music to keep you tied to the game, and have a good time!
I love the soundtracks, they definately make the experience twice as fun.

Plot and expansion potential
There's a lot of potential for this game, such as expansion and sequels.
I really hope they make a sequel to this game, or it's at least considered. This is a game where simply adding more stages, weapons and whatnot, would definately go a long way.
Even the idea of a stage creator/weapon creator so fans can make their own input would be beyond amazing and I think it would create a lot of community based input, where players can download add-ons

I would definately recommend this game.
It's fun, it's simple, and it has a great flow to the game.

20362270.review:
Хороший, но довольно сложный горизонтальный шутер. Игра имеет полную поддержку контроллера, отзывчивое управление и прекрасный саундрек. Что касается самого игрового процесса, то Sora прилично отличается от типичных японских шутеров. 

Имея три вида оружия уже в начале первого уровня, появляется осознание того, что для прохождения придется научится не только вовремя уворачиваться от летящих в тебя пуль, но и осваивать механику стрельбы и ближнего боя. Дабы овладеть основами геймплея крайне рекомендую сначала пройти обучение. 

Важная особенность игры о которой стоит сказать — это умение главной героини уклоняться от пуль и поглощать лазерные лучи от противников при этом давая себе возможность "накопить энергии" для супер удара. Требуется некоторый навык, чтобы делать это эффективно, и людям не знакомым с подобными играми, придется очень нелегко.

Подводя некоторый итог вышесказанному, могу лишь порекомендовать сие инди творение любому фанату японских вертикальных/горизонтальных шутеров и предостеречь тех, кто опыта в подобных играх не имеет, уж больно высока сложность.

P.S. Саундтрек к игре действительно радует уши. Если вы любите транс музыку начала 2000-х годов, то крайне советую купить издание Sora - Blue Sky Edition, поскольку с ним вы получаете 25 композиций в формате MP3, каждая из которых 10/10.

20361804.review: Sora is a fun Bullet Hell that takes you through a much darker story for Orange Juice but very interesting and i found myself losing track of time in this game. The visuals are great too! I would recommend it to anyone that likes the Bullet Hell genre

20355565.review:
At the time of this writing, I have completely beaten Sora on easy mode in a span of 2 hours with the default loadout, no I’m not kidding.

So I think it’s time for me to write a review on this particular type of schmup game that is Sora. Also note that I initially bought another version of this game on GamersGate a year ago which explains how I was able to beat it so easily. The game (on GG) is unpurchasable as far as I know. Of course, this version easily takes that juicy cake.  

To begin with, Sora is basically a unique 2D side-scrolling bullet hell game similar to Suguri from the same company that made the popular board game 100% Orange Juice where you play as a young biogenetically enhanced/engineered human girl and defected soldier named Sora through 9 stages (including tutorial and extra stage) in the Suguri/Sora universe and let me warn you, this thing is shit hard even on easy. I only managed to beat it because of the countless hours I spent on the Ωth’s version.

Now what makes this one different from the Ωth’s is that now it has better translation, window/fullscreen/borderless mode support, better visual quality and all that other fancy smancy stuff.

To the actual review:

[h1]Storyline[/h1] I am quite familiar with the Suguri/Sora universe and thus I could absorbed some of the scenes and reference they made. I don’t believe you need to pick up Suguri first if you haven’t yet since there are little said scenes in these 9 stages. Though if you did get Suguri first then you’ll probably able to piece the timeline together. *cough* [spoiler] Sora is a prequel of Suguri [/spoiler] *cough*

[h1]Gameplay[/h1] One word: “repetitive”. Since even on easy you’ll get rained on by a lot and I mean A LOT of shitstorms coming for Sora’s head, you will inevitably die from turning to a wrong corner. Expect much rage on this one. Heck I even screamed because some boss had a speck of health left and turned fucking Rambo before I had time to shield up. Though by reaching a certain milestone, you can unlock different weapons.

[h1]Graphics[/h1] Can even run on a potato-powered toaster(not really) and looks better than Suguri. The colorful sparks and light effects from beams and explosions are also enjoyable to watch and add to the fast-paced and intensity of any battle. [b] Epileptics be warned. Also for those who played on a potato-powered toaster, things may get clunky if you have too much bullets filling up your screen. [/b]

[h1]Music[/h1] There are tracks that I am not fond of and there are tracks that are one of my most favorite track of all time. Sometimes you just don’t pay attention to the music at all since the high paced gameplay gives you no room to enjoy them. If you get the chance, try to listen to some of them [spoiler] it’s possible to rip them off from the .dat file but don’t ask me how[/spoiler]. There are music tracks with English vocals too. For me those are a nice touch.

[h1]Voice[/h1] There are Japanese voice acting but limited only in the final boss fight. This is just frostings on the cake but you’ll get to hear what the deadpan Sora sounds like. Easily 10/10 out of me

[h1]Controls[/h1] You can play it on a keyboard or a standard XInput controller or even a DirectInput controller. I used the latter (I live in the Stone Age I know). I recommend playing it on a controller. It allows for easier controls and may reduce difficulty significantly for most people since you’ll become more nimble. Keyboard works… but stupid. Just stop… please.

My Verdict  (8.5/10)
A fast-paced bullet hell game that will guarantee you some sort of rage if you don’t have what it takes to dodge any sort of projectile coming towards you. Also requires a lot of reflexes and hand eye-coordination skillz. The game is enjoyable for a few hours and the repetitiveness will get to you eventually except for those who enjoy unlocking new weapons and achieving high scores or just enjoy spending time with Sora in general. *cough* [spoiler] like me [/spoiler] *cough*
Minus one because of a certain bug involving the big ass sword and half a one for repetitiveness.

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/Anonymous_Neko/images/]Check out my nifty Sora-related artworks over at my profile gallery[/url]
